information.general: In 1925, Thor Bjørklund designed the cheese slicer to make even, thin slices of cheese effortlessly.
information.description: He crafted it from wood and steel, with a wire stretched across a flat blade. It glides through semi-hard cheeses like Edam or brunost, turning a tedious task into a quick, precise motion.
information.extra: Bjørklund's inspiration came from the carpenter's plane he used in his workshop. He also experimented with a butter slicer, which failed, but his cheese slicer became a European and Brazilian kitchen classic.

information.general: In 1899, Johan Vaaler invented the paper clip to hold sheets together neatly without damaging them.
information.description: Made from bent wire, it creates tension that keeps papers aligned. Vaaler's design was simple yet ingeniously effective.
information.extra: The idea reportedly came from the need to manage documents in offices efficiently. Later refinements improved durability, and today it's a ubiquitous office tool worldwide.

information.general: In the 1920s, Bruno Linge developed the first clip-on ski binding to improve skiing safety.
information.description: Constructed from metal and leather, the binding securely fastens boots to skis, offering control while reducing the risk of falls.
information.extra: Linge was inspired by the growing popularity of skiing in Norway. His invention influenced modern ski bindings and made the sport more accessible and safer.

information.general: Around 1700, Bartolomeo Cristofori created the piano to allow musicians to play both soft and loud notes.
information.description: He engineered hammers to strike strings, giving the keyboard expressive power. Cristofori's use of hardwood, metal strings, and precise mechanics produced rich tones and dynamic range.
information.extra: Inspired by the limitations of the harpsichord, he experimented with action mechanisms over decades. His designs evolved into the grand and upright pianos that define modern music halls and home instruments.

information.general: Salvino D'Armate is credited with making the first wearable eyeglasses in Italy around 1280.
information.description: Using convex lenses set in wood or metal frames balanced on the nose, these early spectacles improved vision for reading and work.
information.extra: The inspiration likely came from monks and scholars needing to read manuscripts. Over centuries, frame and lens materials advanced, spreading eyeglasses across Europe and evolving into countless modern designs.

information.general: In the 19th century, Angelo Vitantonio built a mechanized pasta machine to streamline pasta preparation.
information.description: Made with metal rollers and cutting blades, it produces even pasta sheets quickly. The machine saves hours of labor compared to hand-rolling dough.
information.extra: Inspired by Italy's love for fresh pasta, Vitantonio refined his design through trial and error. His invention spread widely, laying the foundation for modern pasta machines used in kitchens worldwide.

information.general: In the 1440s, Johannes Gutenberg of Germany invented the movable type printing press. He aimed to make book production faster and more affordable.
information.description: The printing press allowed mass production of books, spreading knowledge, ideas, and literacy across Europe. Before it, books had to be copied by hand, which was slow and expensive.
information.extra: Gutenberg's invention changed the world, enabling the Renaissance, Reformation, and scientific revolution by making ideas accessible to many people for the first time.

information.general: Karl Benz of Germany is credited with inventing the first practical automobile powered by an internal combustion engine.
information.description: The Benz Patent-Motorwagen is considered the world's first real car, marking the beginning of modern transportation as we know it today.
information.extra: This invention transformed how humans travel, trade, and design cities, eventually shaping the entire global automotive industry.

information.general: Wilhelm Conrad Röntgen discovered X-rays while experimenting with cathode rays in Germany.
information.description: This discovery made it possible to see inside the human body without surgery, revolutionizing medical diagnostics.
information.extra: X-ray technology became one of the most important tools in medicine, science, and security worldwide.

information.general: In 1765, Scottish engineer James Watt improved the steam engine to make it more efficient and practical for industry.
information.description: The steam engine powered machines, trains, and ships, changing how goods were made and transported. It fueled the Industrial Revolution across Britain and the world.
information.extra: Watt's enhancements allowed engines to use less fuel and generate more power. His work helped industries grow rapidly and shaped modern economies.

information.general: British computer scientist Tim Berners-Lee invented the World Wide Web while working at CERN.
information.description: The World Wide Web made it possible to access and share information through websites connected by hyperlinks.
information.extra: It revolutionized how people learn, communicate, work, and access information across the entire globe.

information.general: British engineer Frank Whittle developed the first practical turbojet engine.
information.description: The jet engine allowed aircraft to travel significantly faster and higher than before.
information.extra: This invention transformed aviation, making modern commercial and military flight possible.

information.general: In 2014, Colombian engineer Juan David Wills built an early prototype of a force-feedback glove that later contributed to the technology behind modern haptic VR systems.
information.description: The prototype used pneumatic micro-valves and lightweight actuators to simulate pressure and touch sensations. It allowed users to feel resistance while interacting with virtual objects, a major step toward immersive VR experiences.
information.extra: Wills’ early experiments were developed in Bogotá with limited resources. His research later influenced commercial haptic devices used in medical training, remote robotics, and immersive gaming.

information.general: Colombian engineer Jorge Reynolds helped develop early versions of the expandable heart stent while researching cardiovascular implants.
information.description: The device is a tiny mesh cylinder inserted into blocked arteries. Once positioned, it expands to keep blood vessels open, improving circulation and reducing the risk of heart attacks.
information.extra: Reynolds is also famous for creating one of the world's first external pacemakers. His work contributed greatly to modern biomedical engineering in Latin America.

information.general: In the 1940s, Colombian inventor Luis Eduardo Álvarez designed a mechanical coffee pulper that automated the removal of coffee cherry skins.
information.description: Made from metal drums and a rotating abrasive surface, the machine quickly separated beans from pulp, reducing labor and improving consistency in coffee processing.
information.extra: The invention became widely adopted in rural Antioquia. It increased productivity for small farmers and helped raise the quality of Colombia’s globally renowned coffee industry.

information.general: In 1783, the Montgolfier brothers in France launched the first successful hot air balloon, marking humanity's first flight.
information.description: The balloon lifted people and objects into the air using heated air. It inspired fascination with flight and exploration of the skies.
information.extra: The Montgolfiers experimented with different materials and sizes, eventually carrying passengers safely. Ballooning became a popular spectacle in Europe and laid groundwork for aviation.

information.general: In 1864, Louis Pasteur developed the process of pasteurization to kill harmful microbes in liquids like milk and wine.
information.description: The method involves heating liquids to a specific temperature for a set time to destroy bacteria without affecting flavor. It drastically improved food safety and public health.
information.extra: Pasteurization is still used worldwide today for dairy, juice, and other perishable liquids, preventing countless illnesses and saving millions of lives.

information.general: In 1824, Louis Braille, a blind Frenchman, invented the Braille system for reading and writing for visually impaired people.
information.description: The system uses patterns of raised dots representing letters, numbers, and punctuation. It allowed blind individuals to read independently and access education.
information.extra: Braille revolutionized literacy for the blind, becoming a universal tactile writing system used in schools, libraries, and everyday life worldwide.

information.general: A ceremonial flame lit to honor the gods and symbolize the continuity of the Olympic Games.
information.description: The torch was carried in a relay from Olympia to the host city, a tradition to demonstrate unity, endurance, and respect.
information.extra: Modern Olympic torch relays are inspired directly by this ancient Greek invention, blending culture and sportsmanship.

information.general: The Greeks were among the first to use water-powered mills to grind grain into flour.
information.description: Flowing water turned a wheel connected to grinding stones, replacing manual labor with mechanical energy.
information.extra: This innovation became the foundation for later industrial machines and energy use in Europe and beyond.

information.general: Archimedes invented a device for raising water for irrigation and drainage purposes.
information.description: The screw-shaped device rotates inside a pipe or cylinder, lifting water upward as it turns.
information.extra: It is still used today in agriculture and water management systems around the world.

information.general: A systematic arrangement of chemical elements based on their atomic number, electron configurations, and recurring chemical properties.
information.description: Mendeleev organized elements so that elements with similar properties fell into vertical columns, predicting the existence and properties of elements yet to be discovered.
information.extra: This table forms the foundation of modern chemistry and is still used worldwide for scientific research and education.

information.general: Sikorsky developed one of the first successful single-rotor helicopters capable of controlled flight.
information.description: His design combined a main rotor for lift and a tail rotor for stability, setting the blueprint for most modern helicopters.
information.extra: Sikorsky's work revolutionized aviation, enabling vertical takeoff and landing, search-and-rescue operations, and military transport.

information.general: A tile-matching puzzle video game that became one of the most popular and influential games in history.
information.description: Players rotate and place falling shapes called tetrominoes to complete horizontal lines without gaps, which then disappear, scoring points.
information.extra: Tetris has been adapted to nearly every gaming platform and is considered a cultural icon worldwide.

information.general: A popular lollipop on a stick, designed to make candy easier and cleaner to eat for children.
information.description: Bernat invented the idea of putting candy on a stick so it could be enjoyed without sticky fingers, revolutionizing the candy industry.
information.extra: The brand logo was famously designed by Salvador Dalí, and Chupa Chups became a global phenomenon.

information.general: A tabletop game simulating association football, played by manipulating rods with attached figures to hit a small ball into the opponent's goal.
information.description: Gomez's design popularized the game in Spain and beyond, making it a widely played recreational activity in homes, bars, and clubs.
information.extra: Modern foosball tables have evolved in design and rules, but the basic Spanish-invented concept remains the same worldwide.

information.general: The modern design of the classical acoustic guitar, with a larger body, fan bracing, and improved resonance.
information.description: Torres standardized the guitar's shape and internal bracing, improving volume, tone, and playability, forming the basis of modern classical and flamenco guitars.
information.extra: His designs influenced luthiers worldwide and are still followed in modern guitar making.

information.general: In 1876, Alexander Graham Bell invented the telephone to transmit voice over long distances.
information.description: Using wires, a diaphragm, and electromagnetic coils, it converted sound into electrical signals for instant communication.
information.extra: Inspired by his work on hearing devices, Bell experimented tirelessly with circuits until the first call rang through.

information.general: In 1921, Banting and Best discovered insulin to treat diabetes, saving countless lives.
information.description: They extracted it from animal pancreases and purified it so it could regulate blood sugar safely.
information.extra: Their experiments combined surgical skill and chemistry, laying the foundation for modern diabetes care.

information.general: In 1940, Camarena created an early color television system to make broadcasts more vivid.
information.description: His device used color wheels and filters to project images in red, green, and blue tones.
information.extra: He tested prototypes repeatedly at home and in studios, inspiring later global color TV standards.

information.general: Around 1906, Santos-Dumont developed early systems for controlled airplane taxiing and flight.
information.description: He designed wheels, steering, and lightweight structures to safely move and take off small aircraft.
information.extra: Inspired by observation of birds and experiments in Paris, he demonstrated practical flight to astonished crowds.

information.general: Brazilian physicist José Mauro Pinheiro helped develop ultra-flexible fiber-optic strands that improved telecommunication durability.
information.description: The fibers used modified polymer coatings allowing extreme bending without signal loss, ideal for dense urban cable layouts.
information.extra: The technology was later used in submarine cables and satellite communication infrastructures across Latin America.

inventions.name: Direct-Recording Electronic Voting Machine
inventions.inventor: Brazilian Superior Electoral Court (TSE) Engineering Team

information.general: In 1996, Brazilian engineers created one of the world's first national-scale electronic voting machines.
information.description: The device digitized ballots, reduced counting time from days to minutes, and incorporated validation features that cut down election errors.
information.extra: Brazil became a global pioneer in electronic voting. Many countries later modeled their systems after Brazil’s design.

information.general: In 1969, Argentine researchers built early artificial heart prototypes for patients with severe heart disease.
information.description: Made from metal and plastic, the devices pumped blood temporarily while patients awaited transplants.
information.extra: Their iterative testing in labs and with animals paved the way for modern artificial heart technology.

information.general: In 105 AD, Cai Lun refined papermaking to produce affordable sheets from mulberry bark, hemp, and rags.
information.description: He mashed, pressed, and dried fibers into smooth sheets suitable for writing and recording ideas.
information.extra: His experiments standardized a process that spread across China and later the world, enabling literature and bureaucracy to flourish.

information.general: An explosive mixture initially discovered while seeking an elixir of immortality.
information.description: Used first for fireworks and later adapted for military applications, gunpowder transformed warfare globally.
information.extra: Its invention laid the foundation for cannons, firearms, and modern explosives.

information.general: A navigational instrument that shows direction relative to the Earth's magnetic poles.
information.description: The Chinese first used lodestone (magnetized mineral) to create a simple directional compass for navigation and geomancy.
information.extra: The compass later became a crucial tool for maritime exploration globally.

information.general: In 1993, Shuji Nakamura created the blue LED, completing the trio for white light sources.
information.description: He used semiconductor materials like gallium nitride to produce energy-efficient blue light for displays and lighting.
information.extra: After countless lab trials, his breakthrough earned a Nobel Prize and revolutionized electronics globally.

inventions.name: Compact Disc (CD)
inventions.inventor: Kees Schouhamer Immink & Toshitada Doi (Sony/Philips collaboration)

information.general: An optical disc used to store digital data, originally for audio storage.
information.description: Japanese engineers helped develop the CD standard and manufacturing technology, making digital audio widely accessible.
information.extra: CDs revolutionized music distribution and data storage, laying the groundwork for DVDs and Blu-rays.

information.general: A handheld gaming console that popularized portable video gaming worldwide.
information.description: Gunpei Yokoi designed a compact, durable device with interchangeable game cartridges, making gaming accessible anywhere.
information.extra: The Game Boy's success led to a long-running line of Nintendo handheld consoles and inspired the entire portable gaming industry.

information.general: K. N. Dikshit developed a modern shampoo formula to clean hair effectively.
information.description: He combined surfactants and mild chemicals for easy lather and gentle cleansing.
information.extra: The product spread worldwide, transforming hair care from traditional soaps to the global shampoo industry.

information.general: A specialized refrigerator designed to store kimchi at ideal temperatures and humidity levels to preserve flavor and fermentation.
information.description: Unlike standard refrigerators, Kimchi refrigerators maintain a stable, slightly colder environment with precise humidity control, preventing over-fermentation while keeping kimchi fresh for months.
information.extra: This invention became extremely popular in South Korean households and has been exported globally to cater to Korean cuisine enthusiasts.

information.general: A flavored milk beverage that became a cultural staple in South Korea.
information.description: Seoul Milk invented this banana-flavored milk, which became extremely popular and widely consumed in schools and households.
information.extra: Banana milk is now an iconic South Korean drink, often exported and referenced in Korean pop culture.

information.general: The Korean writing system, designed to be easy to learn and use.
information.description: Hangul was created to improve literacy in Korea. Its systematic phonetic design allows almost anyone to read and write Korean quickly.
information.extra: Hangul is celebrated every year on Hangul Day (October 9 in South Korea) and is considered one of the most scientific writing systems in the world.

information.general: Around 3000 BC, Egyptians created papyrus sheets from the papyrus plant.
information.description: They layered and pressed plant fibers to make durable writing surfaces for record-keeping and art.
information.extra: This method spread across the Mediterranean, supporting administration and culture for centuries.

information.general: In 1974, de Jager built the Kreepy Krauly to clean pools automatically.
information.description: Using water flow, it moves and vacuums debris without manual effort.
information.extra: His clever use of basic hydraulics made pool maintenance easy worldwide.

information.general: Around 600 AD, Nigerian artisans created the talking drum to mimic speech and send messages.
information.description: Adjustable strings and tension allow pitch changes, letting drums 'talk' across distances.
information.extra: This innovation influenced music and communication across West Africa for centuries.

information.general: In the 1970s, Kenyan innovators made paper from sisal plant fibers to reduce costs.
information.description: They pulped, pressed, and dried fibers into sheets for school and community use.
information.extra: This creative use of local materials supported education and small businesses.

information.general: Around 900 AD, Moroccan artisans developed tadelakt, a polished waterproof plaster.
information.description: They used lime, natural pigments, and olive soap to create durable, glossy surfaces for baths and walls.
information.extra: The technique spread through North Africa and is still used in decorative architecture today.

information.general: In 1958, Dr. David Warren invented the black box to analyze airplane crashes.
information.description: Encased in durable metal, it records cockpit audio and flight data for later investigation.
information.extra: His tests and prototypes ensured planes worldwide became safer through flight data analysis.

information.general: In 1956, Colin Murdoch invented the disposable syringe to reduce infections.
information.description: Made from plastic and rubber, it is pre-sterilized and safe for single use.
information.extra: His invention quickly became a global medical standard, saving countless lives.

information.general: Fijian artisans designed canoes capable of long ocean voyages.
information.description: Using carved wood and lashings, the hulls were fast, stable, and seaworthy.
information.extra: These designs supported fishing, trade, and migration, influencing Pacific navigation.

information.general: Papua New Guinea communities made bilum, strong handwoven string bags.
information.description: Fibers are looped and knotted into flexible, durable nets for carrying food, goods, and even babies.
information.extra: Bilum remains a cultural symbol and is now appreciated internationally for its craftsmanship.

information.general: Samoan communities developed intricate tattoos as symbols of identity and status.
information.description: Using comb-like tools and ink from soot, designs are tapped into the skin with precision.
information.extra: These techniques influenced Polynesian art and remain an important cultural tradition.

inventions.name: Canaima Educational Operating System
inventions.inventor: Centro Nacional de Tecnologías de Información (CNTI)

information.general: In 2009, Venezuelan software engineers created Canaima, a Linux-based OS designed for widespread educational use.
information.description: Built on Debian, it offers lightweight performance for low-cost laptops. Its clean interface, offline-friendly tools, and open-source structure made it ideal for classrooms with limited connectivity.
information.extra: Canaima was installed in more than 7 million 'Canaimitas' laptops distributed to students nationwide. It remains one of Latin America’s largest open-source educational tech initiatives.

information.general: Dr. Jacinto Convit developed pioneering immunotherapy methods that influenced treatments for leprosy and cancer.
information.description: By combining killed bacteria with a patient's own immune cells, Convit created a therapy that stimulated targeted immune responses. The research helped shape modern immunological approaches.
information.extra: Convit received global recognition for his humanitarian medical work, including nominations for the Nobel Prize.

information.general: In the 1970s, Venezuelan engineer Carlos Soto created the first electric arepa maker, known today as the TostyArepa.
information.description: The appliance presses and heats corn dough evenly between two metal plates, producing perfectly shaped arepas in minutes.
information.extra: The TostyArepa became a household staple in Venezuela and among diaspora communities, shaping how arepas are prepared worldwide.

information.general: In the 1980s, Ecuadorian engineer Luis Armendáriz developed a vacuum-based evaporation system to modernize the production of panela (unrefined cane sugar).
information.description: The system reduces boiling temperature, allowing sugarcane juice to concentrate without burning, improving both quality and production speed. It became important for small Andean producers.
information.extra: Armendáriz’s design increased energy efficiency and created more consistent panela blocks, influencing sugarcane processing across South America.

information.general: In the 1950s, local athletes in Quito standardized the modern net and ball system for Ecuavóley, Ecuador’s unique three-player version of volleyball.
information.description: The system involved a higher net, a specific ball weight, and reinforced court posts, giving the sport its signature fast, powerful style.
information.extra: Ecuavóley later spread to Colombia, Peru, and migrant communities in the U.S. and Spain. Ecuador’s standardized equipment remains the sport’s global reference.

inventions.name: Galápagos Environmental Monitoring System
inventions.inventor: Charles Darwin Research Station (Ecuadorian engineering teams)

information.general: In the 1990s, Ecuadorian engineers and biologists co-developed an early digital monitoring network to track environmental data in the Galápagos Islands.
information.description: Solar-powered sensors collected information on climate, species behavior, and volcanic activity, sending it to research centers for conservation analysis.
information.extra: This hybrid technological–biological system became a model for island conservation worldwide, influencing similar projects in the Pacific and Indian Ocean.

information.general: In the 1990s, Bolivian engineers developed solar-powered systems to improve salt extraction in the Salar de Uyuni region.
information.description: The system uses solar energy to evaporate brine efficiently, increasing salt and lithium yields while reducing labor and fuel costs.
information.extra: This innovation influenced renewable-energy-based extraction techniques across South America, supporting lithium mining for batteries.

information.general: In the 1980s, Bolivian engineer Luis Quispe designed a small-scale pasteurization system for tropical fruits like chirimoya and guava.
information.description: The device uses low-temperature pasteurization to preserve nutrients and extend shelf life, enabling local farmers to export juices safely.
information.extra: It became widely used in Cochabamba and Santa Cruz, increasing income for small farmers and supporting Ecuadorian and Brazilian fruit trade connections.

information.general: In the early 2000s, a Bolivian medical team developed portable oxygen devices specifically optimized for high-altitude cities like La Paz.
information.description: The devices regulate oxygen delivery under thin-air conditions, improving patient survival and comfort in hospitals and homes at 3,500 meters above sea level.
information.extra: This innovation has become a model for high-altitude medical care in Andean countries.

inventions.name: Quipu Digital Archive
inventions.inventor: Pontifical Catholic University of Peru (PUCP) Team

information.general: In the 2000s, Peruvian researchers digitized ancient quipu knots to preserve Inca accounting and communication methods.
information.description: Using high-resolution scanning and data modeling, they translated knot patterns into digital databases to study historical trade and census records.
information.extra: This effort made quipu accessible to global scholars and influenced modern information-encoding techniques inspired by traditional systems.

information.general: Peruvian agricultural engineers developed a low-temperature and humidity-controlled storage system for potatoes, reducing post-harvest losses.
information.description: The system allows potatoes to be stored for months without sprouting or rotting, supporting both domestic supply and export markets.
information.extra: Given Peru’s status as the origin of potatoes, this invention significantly increased food security and agricultural efficiency nationwide.

information.general: In the 2010s, Peruvian engineers modernized the traditional Pukio system, creating a machine that efficiently lifts and channels water for agriculture.
information.description: The device combines ancient Inca hydraulic knowledge with modern mechanical pumps, enabling consistent water flow to terraced fields while reducing manual labor.
information.extra: The Pukio machine preserves traditional Andean irrigation methods while supporting sustainable farming and increasing crop yields in mountainous regions.
